notesStmt.note: The references to November 1862 and to Colonel Robert McIntyre's command of the 16th [West] Virginia constrain the date of this manuscript to between November 1862 and June 1863.
The following are responsible for particular readings or for changes to this file, as noted: Brett Barney Elizabeth Lorang Vanessa Steinroetter Ashley Lawson

body.note: Henry D. Howell, 25 Sanford st. Brooklyn.
body.p:
Benj. G. Howell, co. D. 87th N.Y. Vol. only 19 yrs old 18 yrs of
left Brooklyn in latter part of '61, was in the Peninsular campaign, (in Kearney's division,)—fell was in several battles, FWilliamsburgh, Fair Oaks, &c.; was taken sick, sent to White House, and there removed to Yorktown, where, (as now appears) he died June 12th 1862. But his family, his father Henry D. Howell, for a long time after had misgiving about it. Mr. & Mrs. H. all through the summer & fall, heard nothing from the boy, knew not his death, anticipated every week hearing something. About the 1st of November, a young man came with the story of Benjamin's death. As some important facts

add.p: (The 87th is broken up & (it was the reg't Col Abel Smith was raising when he was killed)

body.p: —Thus things went on, & on Tuesday 21st inst. Mr. Howell came on, with the idea of getting to Yorktown
Mr. Howell, however is now perfectly satisfied that his boy died there at in Hospital, (Nelson Hospital) Yorktown.)
Capt. McIntyre, (formerly a shoe‑dealer in Fulton st.) came out in a command in the 87th NVol.—is now in the 16th Virginia—and a good many Brooklyn boys are also in the
